Study results found:: Greater reduction of food cravings and appetite by choosing a hypocaloric and higher-protein weight-loss diet.
More likely to have high BMI when diet is high in fat.
Fried food intake is especially associated with high BMI.
(Good) Gained significantly less weight on a high fat diet. (Bad) Higher triglyceride levels and risk of early heart attack.
Higher carbohydrate intake linked to lower HDL-C.
Choosing a low-carbohydrate/high-fat weight-loss diet instead of a low-fat diet more effectively raised HDL cholesterol and lowered triglycerides.
Fish oil supplementatiom may not help lower blood pressure.
More likely to be obese on a high saturated fat diet.
AA genotype had decreased risk of type 2 diabetes on a higher fat diet, while TT genotype had decreased risk of type 2 diabetes on a higher carbohydrate diet.
Higher blood pressure on a high saturated fat diet.
Increased risk of Crohn's disease with mushroom consumption.
Being homozygous for the G variant was associated with 8% increased risk of colorectal cancer per 25 gram meat per day.
Greater complex carbohydrate intake ( >= 144 g/d) was protective against obesity, whereas lower carbohydrate intake ( < 144 g/d) was associated with increased obesity.
GG genotype correlated with increased fatty liver on a diet high in carbohydate and especially sugar.
More effectively lowered triglycerides with 3 gram high-molecular-weight β-glucan per day, compared to T carriers.
Benefit from dietary fat restriction in order to lower BMI.
For AA, better insulin metabolism on a low-fat diet for patients with metabolic syndrome.
Lower triglycerides and lower stroke risk with a high-unsaturated fat (Mediterranean) diet.
On average, higher consumption  (~16 grams) of sugar.
More likely to be late lunch eaters, skip or have small breakfast, and lose less weight with slower weight loss rate.
Greater increases in appetite and food craving when consuming a high-protein weight-loss diet (somewhat counterintuitive).
Consumption of less sugar compared to group with other variant (122 ± 6 compared with 103 ± 6 g sugar/d)
Decreased insulin sensitivity when switched from high-saturated fat diet to a low-fat/high-carbohydrate diet or high-monosaturated fat (Mediterranean) diet.
